pros: $37/hr for casual and no benefits

pros: 401K match, union for some

pros: Great career progression and networking
cons: At times you can feel understaffed

review_title: CHH is a good base learning hospital
pros: It all depends on what floor you are on and who you are with. Most of the floors are good. The extern program is a good way to see what it is like to be in a hospital and how it works. They are flexible with your schedule and allow to you prioritize school. They start you out in the float pool which helps you find what you are interested in. As a senior, you can follow a nurse and see the ins and outs of nursing.
cons: As an extern, you are treated as a PCA for the first 2 years. You are also not allowed to do anything a nurse does which makes it difficult to learn without the hands on experience.

pros: Good learning experience, good potential for growth
cons: employee not treated with respect

job_title: Data Analyst II in Huntington, WV
pros: easy going. Great place to grow old. remote
cons: They lied on the interviews about the tools they use. Their pay is below industry standard. Poor benefits. Contractors have greater control over the vision than in house. Most coworkers don't understand technology in department and out. Leadership has little to no vision and is reacting to problems in a complex environment.

pros: Awful management no consideration for employees
cons: Awful management and administration never work there

job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Good pay and benefits, especially for the area-if you're getting paid more for what you do, likely your cost of living is also significantly higher. If you work hard, are loyal, and have a good attitude, you will get to know people within the organization, and they become like second family. Even after I moved away, people from this organization have bent over backwards to help with education, professional development, providing guidance, and more. Organizational leadership from the CEO down are real people who are visible and present/available to staff, and actually do care, they are not corporate elites sitting in an ivory tower.
cons: The organization is experiencing growing pains as a result of the Mountain Health Network merger accompanied by staffing shortages (which are presently nationwide). The growth is positive overall, but it doesn't come without roadblocks, challenges and hiccups. Sometimes the organizational challenges are palpable downstream, however I personally know individuals in high level administration, and they have the best interests of the patients, employees, and organization as their top priorities.

pros: One of the area's best and well-known healthcare providers. Great pay and benefits. Most units utilize self-scheduling and offer a variety of shifts.
cons: Shares similar struggles with staffing that is found nation-wide.

pros: Good pay, schedule is nice
cons: Parking, make your own schedule

pros: Not many pros at all

review_title: Ok, could get better, hopefully now that nurses are unionized it will get better
pros:
Self-scheduling
Regionally recognized Trauma center
Regionally recognized Burn Center
Regionally recognized pediatric center
Union
Recently ratified RN union contract
Decent pay, unified salaries now in place due to Union
Decent medical benefits thanks to union
Lots of security both in hospital and outside
Great nurses and ancillary support staff
cons:
Doesn't value retention
Medical benefits for retirees recently revoked
Takes forever to receive call backs from HR for interviews
Self-scheduling is seniority based which means lower people in seniority are moved to cover needs
Area is nationally noted for the street drugs epidemic
Lots of travel nurses and staffing shortages due to their lack of incentive pay for Covid Relief
Nurses leaving to travel
Covid sick time comes from employee sick hours, if no sick time available, employee can go negative into their sick time but hospital offers no other relief even when forced to quarantine
Retention benefits bare minimum - only thing guaranteed is seniority in scheduling, otherwise there are no benefits for retention, no increases in vacation or sick hours
Mike Mullins is now acting CEO
No tuition reimbursement
Very little equipment for safely lifting and moving patients
Mandatory call shifts for critical care areas

pros: The benefit are still good at the moment.
cons: No respect or appreciation for employees.

review_title: Great opportunities to advance if you're willing to put in the work (I started as a housekeeper, just saying...).
pros: Highest pay for most departments. Great benefits. Education assistance & reimbursement. New construction & upgrades in various departments.  Average working environments. Doctors are mostly easy to work with.
cons:
Administration & management make broad decisions without thinking the process through (Ex. Hourly Rounding forms that has created double charting because it's already done in the computer). Staffing matrix doesn't provide for adequate coverage (Ex. 20 pts will allow us to have 5 RNs on the floor but 19 does not). 
Some departments are unionized.

pros: Great Pay and Benefits. This is a union hospital and is one of the best there is I currently moved away or I'd still be there. Work there 8 years.
cons: you will always have good and bad anywhere you go and generally anything that was an issue could be worked out. I felt like some management tried to be bullies but that's why theres a union.
